petitioner.name: ANDRE LEE COLEMAN, AKA ANDRE LEE COLEMAN-BEY

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 13-1333, Coleman v. Tollefson. Mr. Shanmugam.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Does that include a petition for cert or is it only the first level appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So until there's a petition filed and it's denied or until the time expires to file the petition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sure, it is.  But if -- if that were the case, why -- why would the statute have to refer separately to dismissals for frivolousness by the district court or by the court of appeals?  You could just -- it could have just said, if he's had a petition dismissed for frivolousness period, and that would mean it would have to go all the way up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It separately says by the district court or by the court of appeals.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I think on your theory, he wouldn't get two, he'd just get one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The -- the dismissal is simply not final until the court of appeals acts, and that's one dismissal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No.  I understand what you're saying, but it doesn't make any sense.  It doesn't make any sense for Congress to want a finality rule and yet to count it twice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do you say that?  Where do you get that out of the word "occasion"?  I would -- I would think "occasion" means at any time prior, whether it's at the court -- whether it's at the district court or the court of appeals.  You -- you read it.  Why can "occasion" only mean what you suggest?  Or mean what you suggest, period?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Shanmugam, would you explain that distinction from the court of appeals level?  So the district court dismisses for failure to state a claim.  It goes up to the court of appeals. When would the court of appeals simply affirm and when would it say "appeal dismissed"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Shanmugam, I find it as one of the appealing points in your argument that you have a dismissal for frivolousness at the District Court level.  It's counted as a third strike, and then that is reversed on appeal.  So that, you know, turns out it shouldn't have been the third strike.  And I don't know, what do you do in the last case?  In the next case he has only two strikes.  That is a messy situation.  How often does that situation arise?  How often is it that a District Court dismisses for frivolousness and is reversed by the Court of Appeals?  Do you have any idea?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I hope so, because I don't think it happens very often.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In a case such as that, is there anything preventing the Plaintiff from getting a stay of the District Court judgment?  The third strike, seeking a stay of the judgment, and if in fact it is because of a failure to state a claim, so has more merit than one of the frivolous ones, I suppose the Court of Appeals could grant a stay, and the problem we're addressing would totally go away.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yeah, but that's a problem that is always presented when you have to ask a District Court to stay its own judgment.  But you can also ask the Court of Appeals, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, you just stay the judgment.  Because the judgment -- I mean, that's the typical reason you ask for a stay is because the judgment is going to have some very adverse consequences that should be suspended pending appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  I'm a little confused here.  There's no judgment to be entered if the prisoner can't file because of the third strike.  There is no complaint to stay, and there's no judgment to stay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The remedy will be stayed in effect, of the third strike.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Are you suggesting that the District Court cannot stay the disposition of the case?  Or that a Court of Appeals asked to review it or going to be asked to review it can't stay it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It says the dismissal will Alderson Reporting Company not take effect.  Why can't it say the dismissal -- you know, we think you deserve to be dismissed but weâ€™re going to enter a stay so you can go up and see if we were right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I actually don't even -- I hadn't considered this, because we -- appellate courts have no jurisdiction until there's a final judgment.  There's no 54(b) -- there's no 54(b) standard that would be met and there's no anything standard that would be met.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, isn't that what stays do?  They suspend the effectiveness of the judgment and by doing so you stay any collateral consequences of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The problem here is not that case.  The problem here is the next case, if there is one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought in this case there was no such preclusion.  I thought that the Court of Appeals said, yeah, we'll take the appeal on the strike. So that's -- that's -- you can't urge that issue because you prevailed on it. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But it has to be dealt with under anybody's interpretation.  Once you admitted, which you must, that in one case there can be two strikes, then if there's a second case, a third case, or no, a second case, but a third strike at the District Court level, you still have to face the question of whether there's a right to appeal --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you saying the government is being illogical or inconsistent, because if strike number 3 is a District Court ruling, the government says, well, there's no bar to your appealing that.  There's just a bar for filing a new District Court suit, and you would say that that's just illogical. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If prior occasion  means what it means, then there's only two strikes anyway because there was or two prior cases or two prior --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: By the way, how many of those courts count the time or rely on the time for cert?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?  I mean, what they argue is if we take your interpretation, it has to be final to become a strike, all that takes time, and if you have a really real frequent filer during that year, perhaps you will file 38 more cases or maybe a hundred and there will be no way to stop him really.  You'll have to pay for the -- you know, I mean, you see the problem. On the other hand, the evil that you're worried about, which is that there is a reversal of a strike on appeal, has happened precisely zero times. Ever.  So this sort of undermines the statute.  There's not a real need for it, your interpretation, and if there were by the way and it were reversed, he could proceed under Rule 60(b)5.  So that's basically their argument.  I would like to hear your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, wait.  Wait, wait, Alderson Reporting Company wait, wait, wait.  I mean, what's distinctive about yours is you have to wait for the period of the appeal. You have to -- and, you know, that could take a long time.  And you talk about floodgates.  The reason this statute exists is because of floodgates, because these prisoners file one -- one frivolous appeal after another.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Shanmugam, why isn't this case just a casebook example of what the danger is? Because this Petitioner, as I understand it, filed not only the petition that's before us, but three more.  In what span of time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but he's making up for lost time. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but I don't -- I don't think that your earlier point that when he has two strikes he can file a flurry of suits is relevant. That's -- that's the grace period that the government Alderson Reporting Company has given him.  The government has granted that with only two strikes, you can proceed.  But now we have three, and that's quite different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you know if any of those courts, the majority of the courts except for two, have opted  for addressing things your way?  And -- and I have a slight leaning towards letting the majority of circuit courts figure out administrative -- the ease of administrative rules.  How many of them thought of it as just being easier to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Again -- again, that's a big problem depending upon how frequent that is.  If it's once in a blue moon, you know, it's no big deal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I would think that the -- I would think the situation that we should be concerned about is the situation in which the dismissal, which is initially counted as the third strike, ultimately results in some relief for the prisoner.  And I don't know that there's even one of those.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Lindstrom.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Lindstrom, I -- I understand that argument, and it seems to me a very natural reading of the statute.  But the -- I'm troubled by the scenario where it's dismissed and then it's reversed, not for these practical reasons that people have been talking about.  But it seems to me that if you were really reading the statute that way, that that would count as a strike, too, and that that strike would not go away even when it was reversed. And so I'm wondering whether the statute is actually a little bit more ambiguous than -- than you are suggesting, because at the very least, I mean, everybody agrees that you have to make an exception for that case, and it seems to me that on your reading of the statute, that case would be included.  A strike would be a strike even if it's reversed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes, but that's something -- you're now appealing to some default principle that exists outside of the statutory text.  I can't find any basis in the statutory text for that result. I mean, it's -- there have been three or more prior occasions in which either an action or an appeal has been dismissed.  Now, one of those dismissals was later reversed, but it was dismissed.  And so on your reading, we -- we really, you know, it's -- it's -- your reading is kind of -- this is the natural reading, but we're not going to -- we're not going to apply the natural reading in a case where it obviously doesn't fit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The problem with the Alderson Reporting Company ordinary rule is that it really doesn't apply completely until the next case.  It applies in that case, but it doesn't apply in the next case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Meaning let's talk about res judicata or collateral estoppel.  If it's res judicata, it's the two parties.  So that -- that's that case, essentially.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If it's collateral estoppel, it could be until a third party.  But I think that that third party would be entitled to a stay of his or her action pending the adjudication of the main action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Except that the -- there's still a right to ask the court of appeals for a COA, and so there is an appellate process of sorts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.  Answer -- answer Judge -- Judge Easterbrook's point, that there is no way to revive a subsequently filed case that was dismissed because of a third strike.  Judge Easterbrook, and I think there's some force to his logic, says with this -- this three-strike situation, when the next case comes to Alderson Reporting Company the court of -- to a district court, district court never files the complaint.  There was nothing dismissed that can be revived.  There was no judgment entered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But -- but there's no remedy for the fact that subsequent lawsuits that were -- that were filed based on the erroneous third strike would have been turned back without the filing of a complaint.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And nothing -- or to file a 60(b).

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What does it cost to file

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Sorry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Sort of an interesting question, basically admitting that in terms of your time, the suits would still remain because they could file in State court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do states have similar rules?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You know, I guess what I'm not quite sure about in your answer to my question, Mr. Lindstrom, is, if I understand you right, and tell me if I don't, you're basically saying that we look to these background principles and we decide that a strike doesn't happen if something is reversed on appeal, so a strike is kind of dependent on what happens on appeal. But when you say that, aren't you kind of giving up your best argument?  I mean, aren't you then admitting that the notion of a strike encompasses what happens on appeal and encompasses finality on appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: This is a question I probably should have asked petitioner, but what do you understand his -- what do you understand him to mean when he says it has to be final on appeal? Suppose that there is an appeal pending in one of the prior strike cases, but it's perfectly clear that the notice of appeal in that instance was filed woefully out of time.  Would that be final on appeal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under your position, I suppose we don't have to ask about certiorari, pending Alderson Reporting Company whether or not that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You can say that that's the petitioner's problem, not yours.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What do you think about the government's argument about the third?  You imagine he has -- the prisoner has filed one, dismissed as frivolous; appeal, the dismissal affirmed.  That's one. Now he does it again.  That's two.  And he does it a third time.  District court dismissed.  And he says, I want to appeal that, and I don't want to pay the $500, 505.  And the government has to say -- could say, sorry, you have to pay the 505.  That's the third, because he's a separate.  Then he says, but it says, "on a prior occasion," and this is the same occasion.  And therefore he doesn't have to pay the 500.  What's your view of that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me the government does give away too much in that position.  The only question is whether that undercuts this whole argument.  It gives a little bonus for the appeal of the -- if strike number three is the district court, the government doesn't count the appeal, as I understand it.  It counts -- obviously it counts in a later district court suit, but not here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why use the word "occasion" at all?  Meaning:  What meaning do you give to that word?  Why didn't they just say "three dismissals"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It seems to me you could Alderson Reporting Company have just said, if a prisoner has three dismissals, then -- three prior dismissals; not three prior occasions, three prior dismissals -- he can't get IFP thereafter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What about the fact that this provision refers to a prior occasion on which an action was dismissed?  If you put "prior" and "action" together, isn't there the suggestion that youâ€™re talking about an action that is different from the action that is before the court of appeals in what is arguably the third strike?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Kedem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Isn't that what the court of appeals held here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The court of appeals said you do get the appeal from the third strike.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But is that before us? You -- I thought that this appeal is about the fourth case, and that you haven't -- you haven't contested the court of appeals' holding that you do get an appeal from the third strike.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that's -- that's the -- why I asked the question on page 25 of your brief; you say the bar goes into effect if the prisoners received strikes on three or more prior occasions. Now you say a prior occasion is not the district court dismissal in this third case.  That's not a prior occasion.  But when you look at the earlier two strikes, you don't consider it as a whole.  So we consider this one as a whole, but we don't consider the others as a whole.  That's why I asked the question. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it doesn't -- yes, it does.  Because the dismissal of -- by the district court of this lawsuit after it's done is a prior occasion. The present occasion is your appeal of that dismissal to the court of appeals.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not saying it's good policy or anything.  I'm just saying it's hard for me to see how you can say the one and not the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Good.  And when we're in the second one, when you file the appeal from the first one, the new occasion hadn't started.  So we're still in the middle of the occasion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm going to fail this test because -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Was it your brief that said there were very few cases -- you found only two published cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's what my question Alderson Reporting Company was, okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Then answer Judge Easterbook's point, which is, when the fourth case comes in, the court is just not granting IFP.  It's not dismissing the case, it's just not filing it at all. It's just saying to you, I won't commence the litigation, I won't accept it without you paying IFP.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you -- do you have to file -- pay a filing fee to go with a 60(b) motion?  Is that a separate proceeding?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that would really make your position complicated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And just to be clear, Mr. Kedem, if we say, you know, we're not buying this prior occasion thing, does your -- does the rest of your position stay your position?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Shanmugam, you have four minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Including strikes in Federal courts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Before your time runs out, can a case be final on -- can a case be final on appeal if there is a -- an appeal pending but the notice of appeal is untimely?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So a prisoner could at least Alderson Reporting Company temporarily put some of these strikes in abeyance by filing untimely notices of appeal.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Case is submitted.
